Q7_1: Overall Presentation Content-Introduction, interest in topic, and outline/objectives described
Q7_2: Overall Presentation Content-Defines purpose/controversy of seminar topic clearly
Q7_3: Overall Presentation Content-Objectives clear and useful for self assessment
Q7_4: Overall Presentation Content-Appropriate background information was provided
Q7_5: Overall Presentation Content-Well organized presentations and smooth transitions (appropriate 'flow')

Q9_1: Presentation of Clinical Data-Presented concise objectives, methodology and treatment for each study

Q11_2: Conclusions-Clinical importance and application of the study is discussed
Q11_3: Conclusions-Provided specific recommendations for clinical pharmacy practice
Q11_4: Conclusions-Discussed the role of the pharmacist and/or impact to the profession of pharmacy in regards to the use of the treatment

Q13_2: Question Answer Session-Encouraged questions and interaction with the audience
Q14: Additional comments regarding the question answer session:
Q15_1: Overall Knowledge Base-Demonstrated knowledge of subject beyond the facts presented in the seminar
Q15_2: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to distinguish the difference between clinical and statistical significance
Q15_3: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to look beyond the author's conclusions and offer insight into the overall study results
Q15_4: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to discuss conclusions in the context of previous research and in comparison to current practice/therapy
Q15_5: Overall Knowledge Base-Student is able to think on his/her feet. May theorize if not sure of answer, but identifies answer as such

Q4: Good job of targetting background to audience level.
Q6: Slides were really well done and readable.  The handout had the clides printed in the back which everyone appreciated. Bin referred the audience to the handout appropriately.  There probalby shoul have been more references included on slides, but really critical ones were there.
Q8: Well done overall.  Lots of good things.  The controversy was presented early and clearly.  Many things highlighted in the background were essential for understanding the studies.  Probably should have included Rituximab in the title.  The Objectives were mis-worded.  The objectives are the objectives for the audience.  The should all be able to read "at the end of this seminar you should be able to ..."  Also they all should be measurable or testable.  So things like "review" or "evaluate" are not correct for objectives whereas "describe" and "list" are.
Q10: Bin did a good job of highlighting key results.  Provided an good analysis strengths and limitations.
Q12: Conclusions from studies were well justified.  Overall firm conclusion for the inclusion of the anti-CD20 therapies was appreciated.
Q14: Answered the questions very well.  Just got a little carried away at the end and went a little long.  Really showed himself to be an expert in the area.
Q16: Overall knowledege base was impressive.  Really was able to discuss different aspects of the material.

Q4: Great pace and flow.  Seemed to target the level to the audience well.
Q6: The slides were really well designed and legible, except for those containing tables.  The tables were imported from literature and not legible from the audience.  The writing was just too small.  So either the highlighted sections needed to be enlarged, or the selected data should have been re-drawn.  The handout was useful, probably could have directed the audience to the handout during the talk a bit more.
Q8: Objectives were mis-worded.  The objectives are the objectives for the audience.  The should all be able to read "at the end of this seminar you should be able to ..."  Also they all should be measurable or testable.  So things like "understand" or "assess" are not correct for objectives whereas "describe" and "list" are.  Good introduction and flow.
Q10: Good presentation and analysis of data.  The only weakness was the audience not being able to read the data slides.  The data were nicely highlighted and pointed out, they were just too small to see.
Q12: I thought the conclusion were well justified and that the recommendations for the pharmacist were particularly well done.  It was a good take-home message.
Q14: Good job answering questions.  Handled the one question where she got flustered well by asking to defer it to the end.  It would have been good to ask for that question again at the end, but it is hard to remember to to that.  Otherwise had the answers at the tip of her tongue.
Q16: Good understanding of the material and the larger area.  Was able to describe the actual treatment protocols well.

Q4: Pace was very good.  You had a nice, relatively relaxed presentation style, and excellent eye contact and rapport with your audience.   / Your voice was a bit hard to hear at times from the back of the room.  You might want to use a lapel mic to allow you to be heard more easily while still being able to come out from behind the podium. / You arrived late and started your seminar late.  While issues arise, when you are the presenter, you always want to err on being there very early, so that you can accommodate any delays in getting there.  It also shows the audience that you respect their time.  Additionally, it gives you time to collect yourself and be prepared, rather than having to rush in and start your presentation right away while out of breath.  Don't be late again for such a presenation.
Q6: Slides were pretty good, particularly given poor set up of 2110.  While they still had a lot of text, you added graphs and tables and also cut down and bulleted the lists/material -- that was well done. / Good job orienting the audience to the graphs of CV risk with age.  You did this as well for the data for your studies, but I didn't think you were quite as thorough/good in that case.  Also, it's hard to quickly pick up the red pointer dot on the white screen, particularly when your "circling" with it/moving it around.  Since it's a pointer, point with it -- don't move it all around -- steady point to allow your audience time to figure out where it is in the screen and what specifically it's pointing to.
Q8: You did a great job reviewing patient care, and I liked how you used a patient case to introduce the topic and the question.  A few times you commented on the "new guidelines" and it wasn't clear to me specifically what the difference was between the old guidelines and the new guidelines.  It would have been nice to have a slide contrasting the old and new guidelines.
Q10: I would have liked to see a bit more in-depth commenting on why you thought the stats were appropriate; that is, talk about the type of data being measured and then link that to why specific test "X" is appropriate. /  / You didn't really address withdrawals and dropouts -- there were some, but I think for the question being ask and the ultimate sample sizes, this was appropriate.
Q14: You didn't really stop to ask for questions during the presentation.  It would have been good to do so; for example, after each main section.  However, you did engage the audience by asking them questions and giving them the little quiz about what the patient's risk factor is likely to be.
Q16: You did a good job presenting the material and also answering questions.  It was clear from how you handled the questions that there was, as you said, more knowledge in your head than was reflected on the slides.  When queried about the studies already done and about what you would want to address in the future, you did a great job expounding upon what's already known in the literature and what still needs to be clarified.
Q19: Well done.  Just be on time (actually be well ahead of your scheduled time -- always!)

Q4: You had a nice pace and (aside from jitters early on) were very professional in your presentation. Moving away from the podium can help you avoid the tendency to read off the screen. The presentation was just a bit short, you could have provided a more detailed analysis or added a case study or two to help drive home your conclusions.
Q6: Your slides and handout were good for the most part. One exception was some very small font on several slides (too hard to read, especially from the back).
Q8: Nice introduction, especially the info about your interest in the topic. I was a little confused by your description of your discussions with the physician - did she really say that she NEVER prescribes azithromycin because of the warning that pops up? Your objectives were quite strong, although you might want to narrow it down a little (to maybe 3 things you want the audience to remember).
Q10: You did a nice job of summarizing the studies. Analysis of the studies was a weakness (that will become stronger with more experience, as mentioned in class). It would have been nice to see a more thoughtful analysis of the studies' strengths and weaknesses.
Q12: While your conclusions were supported by the data presented, I would have liked to see you put this into better context for us. We are looking at 15-85 affected patients out of 1 million. The NNT would have been useful, as would a comparison with other drugs notorious for causing long QT. Is this a pretty minor risk, or are they all this minor?
Q14: You got some hard questions, and generally answered well, but were hesitant to step beyond what you'd covered and make a strong conclusion. This is a topic that a community pharmacists undoubtedly encounters fairly often, so you need a strong and determined answer. You did get some good feedback from the audience during the Q&A.
Q16: You seemed really hesitant to draw a firm conclusion. A case study (or two) illustrating when you would and would not want to change the antibiotic would have been useful. It's OK to take a stand. In this case, it seems like, for the vast majority of patients, there should be no concern. And for a few, azithromycin should be avoided.
Q19: Overall, great topic choice, nice first seminar, good job! For next time, you can work on adding more of your own analysis to the mix (strengths and weaknesses of the studies, clinical relevance and applicability, etc.) and taking a stand in your conclusions.

Q4: Nice pace, you seemed quite comfortable presenting. Perhaps move away from the podium a bit more to avoid reading off of the computer.
Q6: Your slides and handout were nice for the most part. You should re-make tables for the slides, they are too hard to read when cut and pasted. You started to orient us to one of the graphs, but then stopped midway through and moved on. A minor point - in your handout, there were several different fonts used. Try to be consistent unless there's a reason for mixing it up.
Q8: The controversy seemed a bit forced here, while it's clear that you don't want to just treat everyone who shows initial symptoms with antipsychotics, what is the standard of care for these patients? Also, the objectives were too subjective - hard to tell if the audience met the objectives at the end.
Q10: You presented the studies nicely, but we need some context. Why did you choose these studies? Is this all that is out there? If so, does that tell you something about the utility of this treatment? If not, are these the best available?
Q12: Your conclusions were supported by the data presented, but the data were weak. Because of this, it leaves the audience wondering whether this has any clinical applicability or relevance.
Q14: You did fine with the Q&A, but next time, dig a little deeper so that you'll have a slightly broader knowledge base to be prepared for questions.
Q16: It would have been nice to put this seminar into context better. Does this really have a place in therapy? Is it a benign enough treatment that you would just recommend it to everyone? Do you expect to see any real results in the larger population? Will the low dose you recommended have any effect (compared to the higher doses in the studies)?
Q19: Overall, nice seminar. Tough topic, tough data. For next time, you could work on putting the seminar into context - where does this treatment fit in the broader picture? Also, be careful about speaking precisely - at one point you mentioned that coconut oil had been used as the placebo because there were no fatty acids in coconut oil. Of course this isn't true, but there is just no EPA or DHA.

Q4: Excellent background to help the audience understand antibody therapy
Q10: The exclusion criteria were not completely clear and would have benefited from additional explantion
Q14: Most answers were good, but some could have been more concise
Q19: Excellent presentation that was well prepared.

Q4: Slight hesitation when presenting some of the data.
Q10: Minor confusion with how the results were distributed among the different age groups - although the presentor did an excellent job showing that the study included their target population, it wasn't clear if the pediatric results were different from the entire study cohort.
Q16: Could try to anticipate potential questions from the audience in the future to help answers be more clear and concise.
Q19: Overall excellent presentation. More practice in the future may help with nervousness.

Q4: Jared had a confident and poised presentation style.  I also like how he moved away from the podium and maintained good eye contact with the audience except when he was explaining things on the screen.
Q6: Jared's slides were clear an easy to read.  I did notice one typo: "site" instead of "cite.  I didn't notice any figures for him to orient.  Literature citations were a bit sparse.  For example symptom slides 4 & 8 didn't have citations (unless they were the same as the CDC citation for the illustrations). Also, the IDSA guidelines should have been cited.
Q8: I missed Jared's interest, but the peer evaluators said it was well done.  The introduction and objectives were good, except for "Introduce Post-Treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome".  In particular, it would be hard for an audience member to introduce PTLDS unless they gave a presentation about it sometime.  Perhaps "be familiar" or "be aware of" would be better.  The Connecticut AG suite made the controversy interesting, especially since the suite did not produce any change in the guidelines. Background and organization were good. /
Q10: Very meticulous explanation of methods, outcomes measures, insightful conclusions and one of the best critical analyses of the affect of insufficient statistical power I've every seen.  Great job!
Q12: Jared did an excellent job of synthesizing complex contradictor data from sometimes under powered studies into very thoughtful conclusions, which formed the basis of his practice recommendations. Role of the pharmacist was good too.
Q14: Great job answering questions!  (I also loved how you deflected one of my questions to Dr. Orlando).  Great job of engaging your audience from the onset and keeping them engaged.
Q16: Superb knowledge of the subject and great critical thinking about the impact of not meeting statistical power.
Q19: Very educational.  You're also a very engaging speaker!  Keep up the good work!

Q4: Nancy had good presentation style standing in front of the podium and maintaining excellent eye contact except when she was explaining things on the screen.  She was a bit nervous and used the filler "you know" several times.
Q6: Instructional materials were excellent.  I didn't notice any misspelled words or types.  Information and data in all sections was meticulously cited.
Q8: Nancy did a good job of describing her interest in medicinal uses of turmeric. Her objectives were well framed.  Her controversy focused on whether there's evidence supporting the efficacy of turmeric in O.A. treatment.
Q10: Nancy did a good job of describing all aspects of both of her clinical studies, though she didn't seem to grasp the impact of under or unpowered studies on negative results.
Q12: Nancy did a good job of reconciling the different conclusions of her two studies and didn't over interpret either study.  Her recommendations for pharmacy practice were well considered
Q14: Did a good job of answering question, though there was some confusion about parametric vs. non-parametric statistics.  At the start of her seminar, Nancy asked if anyone had been asked by patients about turmeric supplements.  This was a good way to encourage audience participation.  For you next seminar, you could try starting your seminar with a case study or quizzing the audience.
Q16: Strong knowledge base about osteoarthritis and medicinal properties of turmeric.

Q4: Great presentation style: Bre stood in front of the podium and maintained eye contact the audience most of the time.  She also made good use of hand gestures and was very poised with confident delivery.
Q6: I didn't notice any misspelled words or grammatical errors.  Also, data and information obtained from published sources was very meticulously referenced. /  / Some slides were a bit busy.  Also, 55 slides was a lot for a 30-minute seminar.
Q8: Presentation content was great.  Bre explained her interest in pulmonology, particularly asthma and CF.  Also she did a great job of framing her controversy.
Q10: I liked how Bre described her rationale for choosing the three studies that she reported.  In general her discussion of each study was thorough and insightful, though she didn't mention whether the third study was powered or not.
Q12: Bre's conclusions were well founded in the data presented in the three studies.  Also, I liked how she made firm recommendations for AZLI as first-line, mono therapy. She also had very well defined recommendations for the pharmacist's role.
Q14: Bre did a good job of answering questions. /  / Suggestion for your next seminar: try including a case study or quiz for the audience at the start of your seminar, then return to it near the end of your seminar.  This is a good way to engage your audience.
Q16: Very knowledgeable about CF and antibiotic use to suppress P. aeruginosa infections.  Great idea to include a clinical relevance slide near the end.

Q4: Overall the presentation was confident and well presented.
Q6: Really liked the font choice.  Sometimes the titles were too close to the top of the slide (note that some projectors tend to crop the top/sides/bottom at times).
Q8: Excellent background discussion.  Sometimes the slides were a bit too cluttered with information.  Even included molecular structures (which med. chem. professors like to see).
Q10: Good presentation of data, although there was lot's of detailed focus and listing of particular numbers which kind of got hard to follow.  When presenting lot's of numbers, you do not have to list them all, but point out general features.  For example, "you can see that all these values, with the exception of X, reached the appropriate power" or "all show the trend that support the hypothesis...".
Q14: Good answering of questions, showed confidence and knowledge of material.
Q16: Clearly the presenter knew her material.

Q4: Mostly did not need to rely on slides, but sometimes the presenter turned to face the screen and left back to audience.
Q6: Good slides and clear transitions.  Some of the fonts may be a bit too small.
Q8: Overall excellent, but could have presented a bit more on the safety of turmeric.  Good background and intro.
Q10: Nice presentation of strengths and limitations and pharmacist perspective.
Q12: Good highlighting about the lack of complete / limited data.
Q14: Excellent job with questions that demonstrated deep knowledge of the subject, despite limitations in studies.
Q16: Presenter clearly knew her data and displayed poise and confidence.

Q4: Good pace.  Took a few minutes to settle in and get comfortable.  Next time, focus on cutting some material and slowing down a bit.  At times it was a b it rushed. /
Q6: Slides were pretty easy to read.  Just a couple of typos in the handout.
Q8: Good description of the background along with interest in the topic.  Like how you referred to the previous seminar from a week ago.
Q10: Overall good presentation of the data.  there were multiple endpoints since the topic was TBI.  This can be confusing for the audience but out you did a good job of keeping it straight for the audience.
Q12: Conclusions were supported b the data.
Q16: Appeared to have a good grasp of the topic.
Q19: For next year's seminar, focus on a concise story so that you do not have to try to rush thru your presentation.  Less would have made your seminar better, since you would not have been compelled to plow thru it so quickly

Q4: Good presentation style, relaxed but not informal. Very good pace for the audience
Q6: Handouts were well done.  Like the inclusion of one of the QoL instruments.  Just to note, the SF36 is a widely used and well validated QoL instrument.
Q8: Good job defining the controversy and introducing a topic that does not come up very often in our region of the country.
Q10: I believe that the power and stats were the strongest part of the presentation of the clinical data.
Q12: Conclusions supported by the articles.  Showing which population may benefit from ABX therapy was very good.
Q14: Did a good job on the questions.  Turfing the one question to Dr. Orlando was a bit of a cope out.  Try to address the question.  If unsure, own it and tell the audience you will check on it and get back to them.
Q16: Good grasp of the issues and the lack of evidence supporting the guideline.
Q19: great job.  No major issues to work on for the next seminar.

Q6: I appreciated having the important components of busy slides outlined by the seminarian - helped to orient the the audience
Q8: It was a little surprising to learn the case study was the seminarian -certainly brought in an interesting human side of the problem and helped relate the problem to real world situations.
Q10: might want to watch out for busy text slides - you don't need to write complete sentences as then the audience reads your slides rather than listens to you /
Q12: Nice job.. i liked how you questioned the clinical relevance of the findings.
Q14: I liked how you stopped at several good transition places to ask questions
Q16: NIce job- as mentioned previously, I liked how you questioned the clinical relevance of statistically significant findings
Q19: I thought Chris did a very good job. There was some confusion as to my email address so I didn't always get things when they were due. But overall, excellent

Q4: Seemed a bit nervous. Which is of course natural.. The more experience presenting, the easier it will be.
Q6: Some of the slides were a bit busy. Also, in the handouts there were charts that were hard to read
Q8: At one point the seminarian mentioned that 'tardive dyskinesia' was a symptom of schizophrenia - but it is a side effect of the drugs
Q10: nice summary of trials - of course one concern is that the two studies were asking somewhat different questions. one study looked at prevention of psychotic episodes while the other looked at the ability of fatty acids to attenuate symptoms...
Q12: conclusions that fatty acids may be beneficial seemed reasonable, especially given lack of side effects
Q14: did a good job of answering questions
Q16: there was the aforementioned issue of tardive dykinesia, but otherwise he clearly knew the background information
Q19: He did a good job. I think it would have been maybe more powerful to have had two studies that asked the same question.

Q4: Carolyn was a bit nervous and there were a number of 'ums' in the presentation. However, more experience presenting will help.. Her nervousness dissipated over time as she settled in, so that was good.
Q6: Carolyn's presentation and slides were the best I saw. Very well done. I appreciated that she highlighted with a box the salient points from sometimes busy slides
Q8: This was an important topic to address. One concern was that her video did not run smoothly. You should always check your videos and a/v set up before hand. However, she did not get flustered so that was awesome!
Q10: she summarized the studies well - easy to follow
Q12: One conclusion you could have made from study one was that penicillin was also increasing the risk of death. this was not addressed.
Q14: She engaged the audience well and allowed for plenty of questions, which she answered well
Q16: one thing to think about though was the age range in study 2 - that might have made findings a bit variable
Q19: Overall Carolyn did an outstanding job. Her handouts were prepared on time, slides were well constructed, and an important clinical question was addressed

Q4: he was late to the seminar, which was not very professional
Q6: some of the slides were very text heavy - which we gave him feedback about. disappointed that it was still a big issue
Q8: the overall presentation was well done.
Q10: i thought given the limitations identified, the seminarian came to strong conclusions as to the benefits of fibrates and niacin add on thereapies
Q12: again, given weaknesses of the studies, conclusions were quite strong
Q14: Did a good job with questions - also gave audience ample opportunity to ask questions - but so well done, there weren't many!
Q16: again, be wary of strong conclusions in absence of good study design
Q19: Mike did a good job. Try to be on time and listen to feedback - be wary of strong conclusions in the face of weak study design
